entry.title: Homogeneous Isotropic Turbulence
entry.content:
By studying homogeneous isotropic turbulence (HIT) we can examine the fundamental building block of turbulent flows, develop the idea of Richardson’s Energy Cascade, and create a baseline state that we can quantify deviations from due to anisotropy or inhomogeneity. The main objective of our study of HIT is to establish a link of the form: velocity correlation function -> velocity correlation tensor -> energy spectrum. We will then turn to Kolmogorov’s theory to establish a link from the energy spectrum -> dissipation spectrum. This will give us insights into the dominant physics at a given spatial scale, and motivate much of the theory in turbulence modeling.

Starting the study of HIT with velocity correlation functions is pragmatically motivated, since velocity correlations and their integral length scales can be determined empirically, and this connection allows us to calculate dissipation rates. Much of this link occurs in Fourier space, where mathematical gymnastics and Taylor’s Hypothesis allow us to move freely between the spatial and frequency domains.

First though we need a couple of definitions.

Homogeneous Turbulence

Homogeneous turbulent flow refers to fluctuation statistics that are invariant to coordinate translations. It is defined as a flow in which the fluctuation statistics are the same at every point in the flow. That is, they depend on only on relative positions and not absolute positions and are invariant with respect to coordinate translations. Mathematically we can express homogeneity in terms of spatial derivatives, fluctuation statistics do not vary spatially.

$\frac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\left(\mbox{fluctuation statistic}\right) = 0$

The implication of only depending on relative and not absolute positions is that the two-point spatial velocity correlation tensor $R_{ij}$ defined as

$R_{ij}\left(\mathbf{x_1},\mathbf{x_2}\right) \equiv \overline{u’_i\left(\mathbf{x_1}\right)u’_j\left(\mathbf{x_2}\right)}$

can be written in terms of separation vector instead of Cartesian position vectors, ie $R_{ij}\left(\mathbf{x_1},\mathbf{x_2}\right) = R_{ij}\left( \mathbf{r} \right)$

Isotropic Turbulence

Isotropic turbulence refers to fluctuation statistics that are invariant to coordinate rotations and reflections. Consequently isotropic turbulence has no preferred directionality. Mathematically, this is expressed as

$\overline{u’^m}=\overline{v’^m}=\overline{w’^m}$

$\overline{u’^m v’^n}=\overline{v’^m w’^n}=\overline{w’^m u’^n}$

$\overline{\left( \frac{\partial u’}{\partial x}\right)^m}=\overline{\left( \frac{\partial v’}{\partial y}\right)^m}=\overline{\left( \frac{\partial w’}{\partial z}\right)^m}$

The implication of this is that $R_{ij}$ can be written in terms of a radial distance $r\equiv |\mathbf{r}|$ meaning that $R_{ij}$ depends only on separation distance and not separation direction: $R_{ij}\left( \mathbf{r} \right)=R_{ij}\left( r \right)$

Longitudinal and Transverse Correlations

The longitudinal correlation function $f(r)$ gives correlations in the streamwise direction and is defined as

$f \left( r \right) \equiv \frac{\overline{u’_p\left ( \mathbf{x} \right ) u’_p \left( \mathbf{x} + \mathbf{r} \right)}}{\overline{u’^2_p}}$

Similarly, the transverse velocity correlation function gives correlations perpedicular to the velocity direction and is defined as

$g \left( r \right) \equiv \frac{\overline{u’_n\left ( \mathbf{x} \right ) u’_n \left( \mathbf{x} + \mathbf{r} \right)}}{\overline{u’^2_n}}$

For a radius $r=0$ both $f(0)$ and $g(0)$ converge to $1$.

Correlation Lengthscales

The correlation functions $f(r)$ and $g(r)$ can be used to define a set of inner and outer length scales: the Taylor Scale and the Integral Scale. The Integral Scale $\Lambda$ describes how long it takes for the autocorrelation to decay to zero. In the eddy viscosity model of turbulent eddies transfering momentum via a diffusive process analogous to the kinetic theory of gases, the Integral Scale can be thought of as the mean free path of turbulent eddies. It and is defined for longitudinal and transverse directions as

$\Lambda_f \equiv \int_0^\infty ! f \left(r\right) dr$ and $\Lambda_g \equiv \int_0^\infty ! g \left(r\right) dr$

The Taylor Scale measures how long $f(r)$ or $g(r)$ stay equal to $1$, ie how long the velocity stays correlated with itself. It is basically the radius of curvature of the autocorrelation function given by a Taylor expansion around $r=0$. It is found from the x-axis intercept of an osculating curve that is the best fit to the autocorrelation function at $r=0$. The Taylor scale falls between the largest eddies at the outer length scale $\delta$ and the smallest eddies at Kolmogorov’s dissipation scale $\lambda_k$.

The longitudinal and transverse Taylor scales, $\lambda_f$ and $\lambda_g$, are given as

$\lambda_f=\left( \frac{-2}{f”\left(0\right)}\right)^{1/2}$ and $\lambda_g=\left( \frac{-2}{g”\left(0\right)}\right)^{1/2}$ where in HIT we find that $\lambda^2_g = \frac{1}{2}\lambda_f^2$.

The Taylor Scale is often used to define a Taylor Scale Reynolds number $Re_{\lambda}$. We will show how $\lambda_{f,g}$ can be related to the dissipation rate $\epsilon$ later, but for now suffice it to say that based on dimensional arguments and the requirement that $\epsilon$ be independent of kinematic viscosity $\nu$, it can be shown that $\lambda_{f,g} \sim \delta Re_\delta^{-1/2}$ where \delta is an outer length scale. Extending this further, we can define a new Reynolds number based on Taylor Scale parameters that are characteristic of inertial range quantities:

$Re_\lambda \equiv \frac{\left(\overline{u^{‘2}}\right )^{1/2}\lambda_g}{\nu}$

Connect $R_{ij}$ to $f(r)$

Connect integral and Taylor Scales to $\frac{\partial f}{\partial r}$ in 2D and 3D using general form for 2nd order invariant tensors and incompressibility constraint

Energy Spectrum Tensor

Fourier transform pair such that $R_{ij}(\mathbf{r}) \leftrightarrow \Phi_{ij}(\mathbf{k})$ derivation of isotropic kinetic energy spectrum function $E(k)$

Governing Equations for $R_{ij}(r), \Phi_{ij}(k),\text{ and }E(k)$

entry.title: Homogeneous Sheared Turbulence
entry.content:
Onto turbulence! Let’s take a look at some DNS data from homogeneous sheared turbulence that I analyzed for a class project. We were given DNS results and had to calculate a number of statistics.

First, we’ll import the data, reshape it and calculate min/max to get a feel for the magnitudes we’re dealing with.

In [7]:
nx=np.array([256,129,256]) #grid dimensions
lx=np.array([2*pi,pi,2*pi]) #domain size
res=np.array(lx/nx) #grid cell size (resolution)

tmpu0=np.fromfile('HST_u.bin', dtype=np.float32)
tmpu1=tmpu0[1:np.size(tmpu0)-1]
hstU=tmpu1.reshape(nx)

tmpu0=np.fromfile('HST_v.bin', dtype=np.float32)
tmpu1=tmpu0[1:np.size(tmpu0)-1]
hstV=tmpu1.reshape(nx)

tmpu0=np.fromfile('HST_w.bin', dtype=np.float32)
tmpu1=tmpu0[1:np.size(tmpu0)-1]
hstW=tmpu1.reshape(nx)

hstUmax=hstU.max()
hstUmin=hstU.min()

hstVmax=hstV.max()
hstVmin=hstV.min()

hstWmax=hstW.max()
hstWmin=hstW.min()
In [8]:
print hstUmax, hstUmin
print hstVmax, hstVmin
print hstWmax, hstWmin

5.8624 -5.1387
3.0338 -3.3306
3.1315 -2.9639

So we’ve got homogenous sheared turbulence with the u-velocity component being sheared in the Y direction. I haven’t shown it, but the boundary conditions are periodic in the X and Z directions. Let’s take a look at the velocities as a function of Y-height in the center of the domain.

Velocity Components

In [16]:
plt.plot(np.arange(0,nx[1])*res[1],hstU[nx[0]/2,:,nx[2]/2])
plt.plot(np.arange(0,nx[1])*res[1],hstV[nx[0]/2,:,nx[2]/2])
plt.plot(np.arange(0,nx[1])*res[1],hstW[nx[0]/2,:,nx[2]/2])

xlabel('Y-direction height')
ylabel('Velocity (m/s)')
legend(['U Velocity','V Velocity','W Velocity'],loc='best')
axis([0,pi,-3,5])
Out[16]:
[0, 3.141592653589793, -3, 5]

We can clearly see the effects of shear in our U velocities. Let’s see how our velocity fluctuates about averages taken over planes perpendicular to the Y axis.

Fluctuating Velocities $u’$, $v’$, and $w’$

In [20]:
hstUmean=zeros(nx[1])
hstVmean=zeros(nx[1])
hstWmean=zeros(nx[1])
hstUprime=zeros(nx)
hstVprime=zeros(nx)
hstWprime=zeros(nx)

for ii in range(0,nx[1]):
    #Means
    hstUmean[ii]=mean(hstU[:,ii,:])
    hstVmean[ii]=mean(hstV[:,ii,:])
    hstWmean[ii]=mean(hstW[:,ii,:])

    #fluctuating component
    hstUprime[:,ii,:]=hstU[:,ii,:]-hstUmean[ii]
    hstVprime[:,ii,:]=hstV[:,ii,:]-hstVmean[ii]
    hstWprime[:,ii,:]=hstW[:,ii,:]-hstWmean[ii]


yval=arange(0,nx[1])*res[1]

The default PyLab histogram function creates ugly bar charts, but we want histograms that Kolmogorov would be proud of so let’s make our own histogramOutline function.

In [21]:
def histOutline(dataIn, *args, **kwargs):
    (histIn, binsIn)=histogram(dataIn, density=1,*args, **kwargs)

    stepSize = binsIn[1]-binsIn[0]

    bins = zeros(len(binsIn)*2 + 2, dtype=float)
    data = zeros(len(binsIn)*2 + 2, dtype=float)

    for bb in range(len(binsIn)):
        bins[2*bb + 1] = binsIn[bb]
        bins[2*bb + 2] = binsIn[bb] + stepSize
        if bb < len(histIn):
            data[2*bb + 1] = histIn[bb]
            data[2*bb + 2] = histIn[bb]

    bins[0] = bins[1]
    bins[-1] = bins[-2]
    data[0] = 0
    data[-1] = 0

    return (bins, data)

We’re now ready to find PDF’s of the fluctuating velocity components

In [27]:
#u' values
for ii in arange(31,100,32):
    (bins,n)=histOutline(hstUprime[:,ii,:],50)
    plot(bins,n)

x=linspace(-4.0,4.0,100)
gaussPDF=normpdf(x,0,1.15)
plot(x,gaussPDF,'k--',linewidth=2)
grid(True)
legend(['u\' @ j=32','u\' @ j=64','u\' @ j=96', 'Normal Dist.'], loc='best')
xlabel('m/s')
ylabel('PDF')
title('HST u\' Probability Density Function')
show()

#v' values
figure()
for ii in arange(31,100,32):
    (bins,n)=histOutline(hstVprime[:,ii,:],50)
    plot(bins,n)

x=linspace(-4.0,4.0,100)
gaussPDF=normpdf(x,0,0.70)
plot(x,gaussPDF,'k--',linewidth=2)
grid(True)
legend(['v\' @ j=32','v\' @ j=64','v\' @ j=96', 'Normal Dist.'], loc='best')
xlabel('m/s')
ylabel('PDF')
title('HST v\' Probability Density Function')
show()

#w' values
figure()
for ii in arange(31,100,32):
    (bins,n)=histOutline(hstWprime[:,ii,:],50)
    plot(bins,n)

x=linspace(-4.0,4.0,100)
gaussPDF=normpdf(x,0,0.75)
plot(x,gaussPDF,'k--',linewidth=2)
grid(True)
legend(['w\' @ j=32','w\' @ j=64','w\' @ j=96', 'Normal Dist.'], loc='best')
xlabel('m/s')
ylabel('PDF')
title('HST w\' Probability Density Function')
show()

These results are pretty cool because we can see that the shear makes our $u’$ velocities deviate from a normal distribution while the other velocity fluctation components remain much more normally distributed.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.content:
Minus Five-Thirds

A blog about turbulence and fluid dynamics

Welcome to Minus Five-Thirds, I’m a graduate student studying turbulence and I will be using this blog to document my research. I’m writing this in an IPython Notebook and I intend for this blog to be somewhat of a digital lab notebook where I’ll put scripts, analysis, writings, media, etc. I’m converting the .ipynb files to static HTML using nbconvert, incorporating them into Octopress blog posts using the setup help found here and then posting to Github pages where I can link the blog to code repositories.

I chose to use IPython notebooks because they allow for an interactive PyLab environment (NumPy, SciPy, MatPlotLib, etc) with inline plotting, LaTex math equations, embedded media, and all sorts of other goodies. I’m stoked about the possibilities. For example, everybody’s favorite equations:

\begin{equation} \frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial u_{i}u_{j}}{\partial x_{j}} = -\frac{1}{\rho}\frac{\partial p}{\partial x_{i}} +\nu\frac{\partial^2u_{i}}{\partial x^2_{j}} \end{equation}

appear quite readily using $\LaTeX$.

I should also explain this blog’s namesake, “Minus Five-Thirds”, refers to Kolmogorov’s famous 1941 relationship between the energy spectrum $E(k)$, the dissipation rate $\epsilon$, and the wavenumber $k$ given by

\begin{equation} E(k)=C \epsilon^{2/3} k^{-5/3} \end{equation}

but more on that later.

The great thing about using IPythong Notebooks is that once it’s finished, I can share it interactively online (great for collaboration), package it up as a python script, pdflatex it for manuscripts, or convert it to a blog post like I’m doing here. IPython notebooks are a great way to make reproducible science, which is important when you come back to a project after a few weeks and can’t remember where you left off, or if you want to recreate results from a journal publication.

Hosting this as a static page on GitHub will hopefully make for a fast and foolproof website that is well integrated with git version control for keep track of various scripts and software development activities.

Stay tuned for more!
